newsitem.title: SPAIN: BA,Iberia talks on hold for American deal approval.
newsitem.headline: BA,Iberia talks on hold for American deal approval.

text.p: British Airways is continuing talks with Spain's Iberia airline on a possible alliance, but cannot finalise a deal until after BA's link-up with American Airlines is approved, an Iberia source said on Wednesday.

The European Commission is currently studying a proposed alliance between BA and American that would give the two airlines control of 61 percent of passenger traffic between Britain and the United States.
"Iberia is in ongoing talks with BA, but BA can go no further until it finds out whether its alliance with American Airlines has been approved," the source told Reuters.
The source said BA has told Iberia that it cannot make a decision before April.

European Union sources predict, however, that the Commission will take no action on the BA-American deal until after the British general election on May 1. The proposed alliance has run into strong opposition from some commissioners who argue it would eliminate competition on a number of routes.
Spanish state holding company SEPI, Iberia's parent, is particularly eager for Iberia to join BA's proposed alliance with AMR Corp's American Airlines, the source said.
British Airways declined to comment on the talks.
"We talk to a whole range of different airlines about a whole range of subjects and more often than not they come to nothing," a BA spokesman told Reuters.
British Airways has also shown interest in investing in Iberia when it is privatised, the Iberia source said.
"BA is interested in taking a stake, which could mean one of two things: either it is interested in an alliance or a takeover considering the size of Iberia," the source said.
However, the Spanish government is unlikely to allow foreign interests to take a large stake in the airline. "BA's stake could be around 10 to 20 percent, but no more," the source said.
KLM has also shown interest in investing in the Spanish airline after privatisation, the source added.
Iberia is eager to start its privatisation process so it can join in the wave of airline alliances.
Spanish law requires Iberia to earn a profit three years in a row before it can be privatised. The Iberia source said the government could therefore sell off the airline as early as July 1998.
"Iberia also wants as much of the airline privatised as possible, but the government is likely to want to hold on to a sizeable share at the beginning," the source said.
The airline could speed up the process with a capital increase that could then be issued to the public, the source said.
